title: Trivial hunting issues sidetrack lawmakers
text:
Bucks try to court fans across Wisconsin Richard Ryman , Press-Gazette Media 10:37 a.m. CDT October 23, 2015 Buy Photo Milwaukee Bucks president Peter Feigin spoke at the Current Young Professionals Leadership Luncheon on Thursday. (Photo: Richard Ryman/Press-Gazette Media) Buy Photo 
ASHWAUBENON â€” After a Packers-like accomplishment of getting public funding for their new arena, the Milwaukee Bucks hope to extend the comparison with success on the court and acceptance across the state. 
The Bucks, who by their own admission have not performed well on most measures of success, are working to improve those metrics and their place in the hearts of Wisconsin sports fans. 
"You've got to talk to fans, lost fans and prospective fans every day," Bucks president Peter Feigin said Thursday, when he spoke to all three demographics at the Current Young Professionals Leaders Luncheon. "We spent the last 12 months re-imaging and redefining who we are." 
The NBA team also spent much of that time convincing state and local governments to help fund a new multipurpose arena and sports and entertainment district in downtown Milwaukee. The $500 million project includes $250 million in taxpayer money, which will grow to $400 million after interest is paid on financing. State funding for the project irked Brown County taxpayers, who found themselves the sole contributors to the Green Bay Packers' 2003 renovation of Lambeau Field. 
"These are all different roads (of financing). The end product is development and growth for the state," Feigin said. 
The Bucks, who last year won their first playoff games in five years, have not captivated fans statewide as have the Packers or the Milwaukee Brewers. Feigin, who was named team president in October 2014, visited a Kohl's department store soon after accepting the Bucks job and found no team merchandise during the season. 
"That's the worst of the worst," he said. "They have Bucks merchandise now." 
Feigin said it's easy to show improvement because the team started at the bottom, in business and on the court. The key will be sustaining and continuing improvement. Winning, he said, will make a lot of things better. 
"Nobody's saying 'I hate you guys.' It's more apathy," he said. 
The Bucks see the Packers' Titletown District as a template for their arena project. The teams have been talking to one another and sharing best practices. 
"Win, lose or tie, you're going back to Lambeau Field," he said. "That's the kind of experience we want." 10-acre plaza heart of Titletown District 
The Bucks opted to play their non-Milwaukee preseason home game in Madison this year instead of Green Bay, the team's long-standing alternate venue. He said the Bucks can play up to two home preseason games outside Milwaukee, and a return to Green Bay is possible, though he did not elaborate on what would be needed to make that happen. He said the team was pleased with the reception in Madison. 
He promised $15 tickets would be available to Bucks games in the new arena, which the team hopes to open by 2017. 
"The first eight rows pay for 90 percent of arena revenue. To not have affordable tickets is insane," he said. "And there have to be free tickets. It's what we think about when we scale the bowl when we build this." 
The Bucks made progress with an improved season and playoff appearance last year, by signing free agent Greg Monroe over the summer and by getting into Kohl's stores. 
"We see tremendous growth, but what's sustainable. You have to have a strong foundation and a road map. I think we are on the right road," he said.
